metadata.case_name: Jhagrakhan Collieries Pvt. Ltd. v. Respondents (Workers represented by Federation)

facts.text: The appellant is the Jhagrakhan Collieries Pvt. Ltd., a Company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act. The Company owns three collieries in Jhagrakhan in Surguja District of Madhya Pradesh. These collieries employ over 4,200 workmen.

At the relevant time there were three Trade Unions functioning at the collieries: 1. Madhya Pradesh Koyla Mazdoor Panchayat (Panchayat) with about 75 per cent of the workers on its rolls; 2. Azad Koyla Shramik Sabha (Sabha); 3. Madhya Pradesh Colliery Workers Federation (Federation).
The Panchayat conducted a complete strike for 57 days in the months of March and April 1968 at the collieries.

The Central Wage Board for Coal Mining Industry by its award recommended payment of Variable Dearness Allowance (V.D.A.), correlated to the cost of living index prevailing from time to time. The Company accepted these recommendations.

The workers represented by the various Unions, on the basis of the Wage Board's award demanded V.D.A. at the rate of Rs. 1.47 per day with effect from April 1, 1968 while the Company was paying it at the rate of Rs. 1.11 per day. The Company refused to pay more than Rs. 1.11 per day.

In December 1968, the Federation, which had a membership of 169 workers (Respondents 4 to 173 herein) made an application before the Central Labour Court-cum-Industrial Tribunal Jabalpur (Labour Court) under Section 33-C(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act (the Act) for determination of the amount of V.D.A. due to the workers.
The Company submitted its written statement on May 13, 1969, challenging the jurisdiction of the court and raised other legal objections.

On October 4, 1969, the Panchayat served a notice of strike under Section 22(1) of the Act on the Company together with a charter of 29 demands and threatened to strike on or after November 7, 1969 if their demands were not conceded.

Conciliation Proceedings purporting to be under s. 22 read with s. 12(1) of the Act were held by Mr. D. Sharma, Assistant Labour Commissioner, Shahdol on the 21st and 22nd October, 1969. In the course of these conciliation proceedings on October 22, 1969, besides other matters, the dispute relating to V.D.A. was settled.
On October 22, 1969, the Assistant Labour Commissioner (Mr. Sharma) sent a report together with a copy of the settlement to the Government, as required by Section 12(3) of the Act.

Subsequent to the signing of this conciliation agreement, dated October 22, 1969, the Company filed a supplementary statement on November 5, 1969, submitting that in view of the said settlement, the application under s. 33C(2) of the Act filed by the Federation, had become infructuous.
The Labour Court by its order, dated December 20, 1969 framed this additional issue: Whether the claim stands settled by reason of settlement dated 22-10-1969, if any.

On behalf of the workers several objections were raised to the enforceability of this settlement. Their ultimate stand was that the settlement was not in accordance with the provisions of the Act, inasmuch as it had not been brought about in proceedings before a duly appointed Conciliation Officer.

The Labour Court tried this issue as a preliminary issue. It held that Shri Sharma was not a duly appointed Conciliation Officer on the date on which the settlement was arrived at, and consequently, it did not put an end to the dispute pending before the Labour Court.

To impugn this order of the Labour Court, the Company through its agent and Mining Engineer filed a Writ Petition under Article 226 and 227 of the Constitution, which was dismissed by the Madhya Pradesh High Court by judgment dated August 4, 1971.

legal_issues.text: Whether the settlement dated October 22, 1969 was a settlement in the course of conciliation proceedings under the Act, binding under s.18(3)
Whether the settlement, even if not under conciliation proceedings, is binding on respondents 4 to 173 under s.18(1) due to acceptance by 99% of workers
Whether the Labour Court erred in refusing permission to lead evidence on implementation and acceptance of the settlement by 99% workers, violating natural justice
Whether there is anything in the Act prohibiting settlement during pendency of s.33C(2) proceedings, and if such settlement binds non-parties

petitioner_arguments.text: In holding that the settlement dated October 22, 1969 was not a settlement in the course of conciliation proceedings, the courts below misconstrued Section 4 of the Act, relying only on sub-section (1) and not sub-section (2) and notification thereunder. (Withdrawn)

Assuming the settlement was not in conciliation proceedings and binding under s.18(3), it was still binding on workmen including respondents 4-173 when 99% of total workmen accepted it, including V.D.A.
Labour Court's order refusing permission to lead evidence to prove implementation and acceptance by 99% workers was violative of natural justice.
Nothing in the Act prohibits settlement during pendency of s.33C(2) proceedings; settlements inter se preferred to adjudication.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.33C(2) ID Act; Amalgamated Coffee Estates Ltd. v. Their workmen; Sirsilk Ltd. v. Govt of AP

respondent_arguments.text: The settlement was not in accordance with the Act as it was not brought about in proceedings before a duly appointed Conciliation Officer.
An implied agreement by acquiescence or conduct such as acceptance of benefit under an agreement to which worker was not party is not binding under s.18(1) or (3).

court_reasoning.text: Section 2(p) defines settlement as: (i) arrived at in conciliation proceedings; or (ii) written agreement otherwise, signed in prescribed manner and copy sent to officer. Effect under s.18(3) for first kind (binding all workmen), s.18(1) for second (binding parties only).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Settlement not in course of valid conciliation as Sharma not duly appointed; High Court finding unassailed.

court_reasoning.text: Respondents 4-173 not parties/signatories to settlement; implied acceptance by 99% via drawing VDA not a 'settlement' under s.2(p) as not written/signed/prescribed; not binding under s.18(1) or (3).

Labour Court decided preliminary issue of law on record; no prejudice as even assuming 99% acceptance, claim not settled qua respondents; evidence allowable on remaining issues; settlement binding on contracting parties under s.18(1).
s.33C(2) executing provision, narrower than s.10(1); Amalgamated Coffee distinguishable (s.10(1) appeals, fair settlement by most); non-parties not bound.

holdings.text: Settlement not arrived at in course of conciliation proceedings under Act; not binding under s.18(3) on all workmen.
Even if accepted by 99% workers, not a 'settlement' under s.2(p)/(18); not binding on non-parties like respondents 4-173.
Labour Court refusal to allow evidence on preliminary issue caused no prejudice.
Settlement during s.33C(2) pendency binds only parties thereto.

precedents_cited.case_name: Amalgamated Coffee Estates Ltd. and ors. v. Their workmen and others
precedents_cited.relevance: Settlement in s.10(1) appeals accepted as fair by most; distinguishable from s.33C(2) execution proceedings.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Sirsilk Ltd. and ors. v. Government of Andhra Pradesh and anr.
precedents_cited.relevance: Relied on by petitioner; context of settlements preferred.

precedents_cited.case_name: East India Coal Company Ltd. Banares Colliery, Dhanbad v. Raweshwar and Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: s.33C(2) wider than 33C(1) but narrower than s.10(1); executing provision.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Defined settlement; binding effect; conciliation; strike notice; computation of benefits.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petition filed by company against Labour Court order.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding the Labour Court and High Court orders. The settlement dated October 22, 1969, not being in valid conciliation proceedings, is not binding under s.18(3) on all workmen; even if accepted by 99%, not binding on non-parties under s.18(1) in s.33C(2) proceedings.

key_quotes.text: "a settlement arrived at in the course of conciliation proceedings under this Act ... shall be binding on- ... all persons who were employed in the establishment ... on the date of the dispute"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains broad binding effect of s.18(3) settlements, not applicable here.

key_quotes.text: "an implied agreement by acquiescence, or conduct such as acceptance of a benefit under an agreement in which the worker acquiescing or accepting the benefit was not a party being outside the purview of the Act, is not binding"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects petitioner's argument on implied acceptance binding non-parties.

key_quotes.text: "The provisions of S. 33-C are, broadly speaking, in the nature of executing provisions."
key_quotes.speaker: court
